awd_titl_txt: Constraining properties of pyroclastic density currents with remote infrasound and seismic observations
awd_abstract_narration:
Pyroclastic density currents (PDCs) are hot mixtures of eruption-derived particles and gas that move laterally along the ground.  PDCs are commonly generated by eruption column or lava dome collapse and are driven by negative buoyancy.   Due to their mobility, rapid velocities, and high temperatures, PDCs are the most hazardous volcanic phenomena and are responsible for over 50% of volcanic-related fatalities. PDCs are also challenging to observe directly.  In addition to their hazardous nature, PDCs occur infrequently and often are located in remote and inhospitable places.  Furthermore, direct visual observations can usually only be made  of  the  outer  shell  of  the  flow  as  the complex internal dynamics are obscured by visually opaque fluid.  Therefore, most of our understanding about these multiphase, turbulent flows comes from geological observations of PDC deposits, laboratory studies and numerical models. This work extends knowledge of PDC dynamics by associating physical processes with seismic and infrasonic waves. Geophysical observations (infrasound and seismic) can be made at safe distances from PDC activity and can provide high-resolution information about PDC dynamics. This project also supports a postdoctoral scholar, who will engage in activities that bring STEM and natural hazard resources to schools in the Cascadia region.

For this project we will be developing a quantitative framework to relate PDC properties and dynamics to geophysical observables. The researchers will perform 3D multiphase simulations of PDCs and compute the infrasound and seismic radiation. This will enable the investigators to directly compare the simulation outputs with field data, which will provide a way to validate and improve numerical models of PDC dynamics.  The researchers will perform a sensitivity analysis to understand what properties the geophysical observables are sensitive to and will explore the geophysical signals of different physical processes that have been shown to be important to PDC dynamics, such entrainment and fluidization.  The proposed work will increase fundamental scientific understanding about the processes governing PDCs and will aid in data interpretation and volcano monitoring efforts by developing quantitative links between geophysical observables and flow properties.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Pyroclastic density currents (PDCs) are the most hazardous volcanic phenomena and are responsible for over 50% of volcano-related fatalities. PDCs are hot mixtures of eruption-derived particles and gas that are generated by collapse of an eruption column or lava dome and can travel large distances at great velocities. Our understanding of the processes governing these complex, multiphase and turbulent flows is limited because PDCs are dangerous and challenging to observe directly. However, PDC activity frequently generates geophysical signals - infrasound (low frequency acoustic waves) in the atmosphere and seismic waves in the solid Earth - that can be safely recorded at remote distances. In recent years, there have been an increasing number of geophysical observations of PDC activity. Much of this work has been observational and there remains no quantitative framework to relate PDC properties to the observed geophysical signals.

 

This grant supported postdoctoral researcher who modified a numerical model to simulate PDC dynamics and computed the associated infrasound and seismic radiation. This grant led to the development of integral methods to examine infrasound from both plume and PDC sources. Further, multiphase flow models of PDC were coupled to this approach to link propagated acoustic signals with flow conditions. Further work was done using discrete element simulations that can resolve individual particles to compute numerous individual collisions with the ground to better examine seismic sources. These detailed source-physics models have been coupled to both wave form simulations and to empirical approaches to examine the seismic radiation from these sources.

 

This work aids the interpretation of data from hazardous volcanoes, and provides valuable information for planning future instrument deployments. The simulation framework developed here can also now be applicable to other particle-laden gravity currents, such as lahars, debris flows and turbidity currents. Validation of numerical approaches for PDC dynamics remains a topic of intense interest. Previous studies have compared simulation results to geological observations of PDC deposits but these only provide an incomplete snapshot of the complex and time-varying processes governing PDC dynamics. Validation work has also been done recently on large scale experiments, some large enough to produce measurable geophysical signals. The work done here enables PDC simulations to be directly compared to geophysical observables, which will improve model validation. In addition to the broader impact of developing better tools to interpret the signals from hazardous flows, this work resulted in material that was used for outreach to elementary school classrooms, and in the training of a postdoctoral researcher.
